project.teaser: The incineration of biomass, municipal solid waste and sewage sludge produces significant quantities of ashes in the EU: approximately 25 million tons annually. These residues have currently no use or they are utilized only in low-value applications. Major problems with the...
project.objective: The incineration of biomass, municipal solid waste and sewage sludge produces significant quantities of ashes in the EU: approximately 25 million tons annually. These residues have currently no use or they are utilized only in low-value applications. Major problems with the use of incineration residues in the construction, water treatment, and other industries are insufficient public awareness of the safety and environmental acceptability of the final products , the lack of uniform regulations, and readiness of the market to accept incineration residues as a supplementary material. The project AshCycle will demonstrate and implement industry-urban symbioses revolving around the underutilized ashes to reach circular and climate neutral economy in Europe. Pilots and replication demonstrations will be carried out in Denmark, Finland, Belgium, The Netherlands, Croatia, Slovenia, Switzerland, and South Africa. The symbioses will include all major actors from the value chains, namely ash providers, ash beneficiation handlers, concrete and adsorbent product providers, as well as engagement of general public. AshCycle answers unmet socio-economic demands, facilitates emerging ash-based circular products for market entry and to unlocks benefits for society by acceptance of new circular concepts.
project.title: Integration of Underutilized Ashes into Material Cycles by Industry-Urban Symbiosis
project.keywords: ashes, construction materials, adsorbents, resource recovery

result.teaser: The AshCycle project provides tools for reducing the waste generation from the incineration of municipal solid waste, biomass, and sewage sludge by developing resource recovery and new utilization possibilities for the mineral residue. Currently, the ashes resulting from these...

result.title: Concrete pavers with wood biomass ash

details.authors: Ćosić, Marija
details.journalTitle: Final thesis - Banjad Pečur, Ivana (mentor)
details.publisher: University of Zagreb Faculty of Civil Engineering

result.title: I-US model, KPIs and impact indicators
result.description: This reports includes mapping of value chain networks, including geographical locations and material flows between the actors, emissions, and costs associated with transportation of materials. Comparing the decentralized and centralized value chain networks, the most optimal network designs within I-US will be defined using mixed integer linear optimization method. The potential for (re)allocating pre-treatment plants to minimize environmental impacts and emissions associated with transportation will be estimated. The model will be set up using available data from literature and databases (Eurostat, national statistics), the scenarios will be verified through the pilots to examine patterns at regional scale. Each of the AshCycle I-US pilots will be described in terms of residue/resource flow and modelled applying the indicators and measures developed in Task 1.2. To measure the scalability and the potential environmental and societal impact of creating the AshCycle I-US, we will develop a set of indicators to be used for modelling the environmental, economic, and societal impact of the pilots and the scalability potential.

result.title: CO2 capture by selected ashes and LCA
result.description: This deliverable reports the findings on the carbon capacity storage of the ashes (sequestration potential). Such process might become part of incineration plants, and it provides two benefits; stabilized ash and reduction of CO2 emissions or it can take place through the long-term use of ashes. The results of potential of temporary carbon storage capacity will be critically and adequately assessed within Life cycle assessment (Global Warming Potential indicator). Also, the carbon sequestration will be studied in view of carbstone concrete products.

result.title: Integration of underutilized ashes into material cycles by industry-urban symbiosis

details.authors: Štirmer, Nina; Carević, Ivana; Serdar, Marijana; Cerković, Sonja; Banjad Pečur, Ivana
details.journalTitle: 17th Days of the Croatian Chamber of Civil Engineers

result.title: LCA&GIS tool
result.description: To assess environmental impacts associated with the I-US, combination of LCA and GIS methods will be used. The quality of ashes produced by incinerators and volumes of recovered and residue materials will differ spatially and temporarily. The final application of ashes depends on their typology and pre-treatment technologies as examined in WP4. The detailed LCA of pilot products is performed in WP6. The life cycle inventory data collected in WP6 will be used to quantify the environmental impacts of dynamic scenarios of ash applications, comparing pre-treatment options and final mix designs. Using GIS tool, transportation distances between all potential actors will be examined in a network analysis to minimize associated emissions and identify optimal supply chain directions. The algorithms will be developed to integrate impacts associated with the pre-treatment of ashes, transportation and production of construction materials into the LCA results and interactively show the most optimal application for the produced batches of ashes. The LCA and GIS tool will be integrated with AMA tool developed in Task 1.4.

result.title: Characterization and categorization of the ashes
result.description: The results of the characterization of the ashes (i.e., chemical composition, physical and chemical properties) are presented. The ashes will be categorized into groups with critical characteristics (e.g., chemical composition/undesired elements and reactivity) taken as criteria. The groups will be rated into different levels. Lower level of a certain group of ashes means more efforts of pre-treatment will be needed before utilization.

result.title: Project website
result.description: Website for project will be launched with information about the project and recent news.

category.title: waste treatment processes
category.displayCode: /engineering and technology/environmental engineering/waste management/waste treatment processes

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
